thread.title: Three of the best driving routes in Europe
thread.title_full: Three of the best driving routes in Europe - Telegraph

author: Rachel Halliwell
title: Three of the best driving routes in Europe
text: When you’re looking for a holiday destination that’s exotic but not too far from home, Europe is an obvious choice. But instead of settling in at a touristy resort, why not hire a car and do a bit of exploring? The best way to explore a new area is by setting your own agenda. Try one of these stunning driving routes during your next visit abroad. The Amalfi Coast One of Italy's most scenic stretches of coastline, the Amalfi Coast was awarded a coveted spot on the World Heritage list in 1997 Photo: Corbis Driving route: Starting in the bustling port of Salerno, you will pick up the SS163 at Vietri sul Mare and pass through Ravello, Amalfi, Praiano and Positano before arriving at the resort of Sorrento, 66 miles later. Time needed: Without stop-offs this drive would take up to four hours. But with so much to see, you should allow a full day. Key features: The Amalfi Coast is one of Italy's most scenic stretches of coastline and was awarded a coveted spot on the World Heritage list in 1997. Little wonder, with its meandering coastal roads through a landscape of painted villages terraced into hillsides and incredible views over turquoise waters. Where to stop: Ravello is one of the most romantic and beautiful small towns in southern Italy, once described by French novelist André Gide as being closer to the sky than the sea. Amalfi makes a great spot for lunch, with plenty of cafés on its scenic seafront, and is home to the ninth-century Duomo di Sant'Andrea cathedral. Your destination, Sorrento, is a popular but beautiful and sophisticated old town resort, with stunning views. Along the French Riviera Azure seas and glorious golden sands: This coastline was one of the first modern resort areas Photo: Getty Driving route: Starting in Nice – a good place to fly into – you will overnight in Vence before heading over to Antibes, with your 62-mile trip ending in the world-famous Monte Carlo. Time needed: Three days. Key features: This coastline, with its azure seas and glorious golden sands, was one of the first modern resort areas and has inspired many great artists. Picasso made a home here, as did Chagall and Matisse. If you want glamour, this is where you’ll find it – the French Riviera has been considered the playground of the rich and famous for almost a century. Where to stop: Nice is France’s second most popular city for tourists and a bustling metropolis where you can wile away several hours exploring the side-streets and alleyways. The famous Notre Dame cathedral is well worth a visit. Spend your second day in the quaint seaside resort of Antibes, where Picasso spent six months in a sea-facing château painting his masterpieces. Your trip ends in Monaco, where you might like to take your chances at the world-famous Monte Carlo Casino. The Atlantic Road, Norway Wild coastline and bridge architecture: The Atlantic Road has been awarded the status of national tourist route Photo: Getty Driving route: The Atlantic Road is a five-mile stretch of road between the towns of Kristiansund and Molde, the two main population centres in western Norway. This remarkable route zigzags across 12 low bridges that jut out over the sea. Time needed: You can do it in 30 minutes, but the views are truly spectacular, so take your time and make at least one stop along the way. Key features: The Atlantic Road has been awarded the status national tourist route because of the architecture of the road and the bridges, as well as the incredible wild coastline it passes through. In calm weather you might even see whales and seals. Where to stop: The largest rest area along the Atlantic Road is at Eldhusøya Island, beautifully situated at the edge of the ocean. For all your roadside needs, the AA is there to help. Find out more at theaa.com
